The week in data: Love at first spreadsheet¬†‚ù§¬†üíª

Your round-up of the latest, greatest data stories

Your round-up of the latest, greatest data stories
http://theodi.org?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]
http://theodi.org/news?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]


** Dear Joel,
------------------------------------------------------------
Love is in the air this week, so we‚Äôve been celebrating Love Data Week (http://lovedataweek.org/?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) ‚Ä¶ because, well, that‚Äôs how we roll. According to NHS data, being loved up on Valentine‚Äôs Day causes a mini baby boom (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-43058389?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) . Slightly more tenuously, another piece claims the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is like Valentine‚Äôs Day for brands (https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/why-gdpr-day-valentines-day-brands/1457045?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) , since it will help them get closer to their customers. Aww.

But before we start a rendition of ‚ÄòWhy do brands suddenly appear‚Äô and reach for the heart-shaped chocolates, a sobering piece from the Guardian has reminded us that chocolate causes deforestation (https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/14/valentines-day-chocolates-may-not-be-the-greenest-way-to-show-your-love?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) , drawing on import-export data on cocoa in five countries.

Finally, it‚Äôs been a big week for ODI launches: results from a YouGov poll (https://theodi.org/blog/odi-survey-reveals-british-consumer-attitudes-to-sharing-personal-data-online?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) that shows people feel more comfortable sharing data about them with the NHS than with their own friends and family, lots of research into data standards (https://theodi.org/blog/open-standards-for-data-adoption-approaches-and-impact?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) and a piece on the exciting innovations that GDPR will bring (https://theodi.org/blog/will-gdpr-and-data-portability-support-innovation?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) . Being able to listen to our Spotify playlists on iTunes? We wouldn‚Äôt say no...

Until next time,

Hanna (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) h (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) , Anna (http://theodi.org/team/anna-scott?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  and Caley

** Open standards for data: adoption, approaches and impact (https://theodi.org/blog/open-standards-for-data-adoption-approaches-and-impact?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )
------------------------------------------------------------
Open standards are important to our data infrastructure. To mark the launch of new research, researchers Edafe Onerhime and Rose Rees-Jones share their findings on how people approach developing standards and what they need, and the impact of open data standards


** Will GDPR and data portability support innovation? (https://theodi.org/blog/will-gdpr-and-data-portability-support-innovation?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=16cdd9a5f1-TheWeekinData16Feb2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-16cdd9a5f1-101341833&mc_cid=16cdd9a5f1&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )

The Week in Data: Feeding the world, LMAO and Bob Geldof on GDPR

Your round-up of the latest, greatest data stories

Your round-up of the latest, greatest data stories
http://theodi.org?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]
http://theodi.org/news?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]


** Dear Joel,
------------------------------------------------------------
As we to our new year health-kicks and dry/veganuary pledges, we see a focus on health and nutrition data this week. The US Department of Agriculture has pondered whether open data could feed the world (https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/can-open-data-feed-world/41419/?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) , the New York Times has featured a new study on diet data (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/25/well/eat/data-dieting-weight-gain-loss-fat-genes.html?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) , and the World Health Organisation has published the first ever platform for standardised data on burns (http://www.thedailystar.net/health/first-global-platform-data-collection-burns-launched-1523428?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) .

Ever wondered how your favourite poems might be valued by Google Adwords? We‚Äôre excited that WIRED have covered üòπLMAO (http://www.wired.co.uk/article/google-adwords-poetry-open-data-institute-pip-thornto?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) ‚Äì our new art exhibition, launched last week, which that finds the humorous side of data.

And finally, Bob Geldolf has been busy at the BETT 2018 conference (http://www.trustedreviews.com/news/gdpr-2018-compliance-deadline-uk-dates-fines-schools-bett-2018-bob-geldof-3382102?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]#2ztJb1sptMGfpK6y.99 ) this week speaking out against ‚Äòscaremongering‚Äô about the General Data Protection Regulation, coming into force in May. An unlikely spokesperson, but did the job of getting the conference in the press‚Ä¶ and into this newsletter.

Enjoy!

Hanna (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) h (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  , Anna (http://theodi.org/team/anna-scott?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  and Caley
ODI Production Team


** From the outside world
------------------------------------------------------------


** Can open data feed the world? (https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/can-open-data-feed-world/41419?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID])
------------------------------------------------------------
Open Access Government

This piece argues that if we‚Äôre going to feed the world, we need open data policies in governments to be able to make strong decisions based on facts and evidence


** Orwell's 1984 is worth ¬£58,318, according to Google AdWords (http://www.wired.co.uk/article/google-adwords-poetry-open-data-institute-pip-thornton?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )
------------------------------------------------------------
Wired

Our current exhibition, üòπLMAO, at the ODI was yesterday covered in Wired, highlighting Pip Thornton‚Äôs work that looks at how renowned poems are valued on Google Adwords


** Big data comes to dieting (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/25/well/eat/data-dieting-weight-gain-loss-fat-genes.html?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=2fc5bb7194-TheWeekinData19Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-2fc5bb7194-101341833&mc_cid=2fc5bb7194&mc_eid=[UNIQID])

Your round-up of the latest, greatest data stories
http://theodi.org?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID]
http://theodi.org/news?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID]


** Dear Joel,
------------------------------------------------------------
Happy New Year! (We know we said we‚Äôd be back on 12 January but, hey, we missed you all too much to wait another week.)

Have you made any new year‚Äôs resolutions? Finally get that guitar out of its case, maybe? Start a smoothie diet? Become fluent in Mandarin? Well, ours is less outlandish: get more sleep. This week, having analysed a whopping 6 billion nights of sleep, FitBit have found that going to bed at the same time each night will get you the best night‚Äôs kip (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/04/fitbit-data-a-consistent-bedtime-routine-creates-better-quality-sleep.html?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) . Who knew?

Also this week, we‚Äôve launched a report looking at how to take an open approach to investment banking (https://theodi.org/an-openapproach-to-investmentbanking?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) . It considers the sector‚Äôs data infrastructure, where data assets are on the Data Spectrum, and how we can use open data to create a strong data economy. We‚Äôve also launched new research into the impacts of peer-to-peer accommodation (https://theodi.org/blog/what-are-the-impacts-of-peertopeer-accommodation-platforms?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) and how data could help improve it, for you to read and comment on.

Finally, since most of us were too busy binge-eating and watching movies in the past few weeks to read blogs, we‚Äôve gathered some great ones you may have missed. These include a piece on why we should care about data portability (http://www.jenitennison.com/2017/12/26/data-portability.html?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) from our CEO, Jeni, and a piece on using AI and open data for innovation and accountability (https://theodi.org/blog/using-artificial-intelligence-and-open-data-for-innovation-and-accountability?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] ) from our Head of Tech, Olivier.

Until next time,

Anna (http://theodi.org/team/anna-scott?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  and Hanna (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) h (https://theodi.org/team/hannah-foulds?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID])
ODI Production Team


** From the outside world
------------------------------------------------------------


** FitBit say stick to your bedtime for better sleep (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/04/fitbit-data-a-consistent-bedtime-routine-creates-better-quality-sleep.html?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )
------------------------------------------------------------
CNBC

Fitbit tracked 6 billion nights‚Äô sleep and that found that if your bedtime varies by two hours over the week, you'll average a half hour of sleep a night less than someone whose bedtime varies by only 30 minutes


** OpenStreetMap‚Äôs asks of the Geospatial Commission (https://osmuk.org/pinned/our-asks-of-the-geospatial-commission?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )
------------------------------------------------------------
OpenStreetMap UK

OpenStreetMap UK call on government to develop systems-thinking, treat data as infrastructure and see there is more value in applications than in data itself. They also make six strategic policy asks for stronger geospatial data infrastructure


** Personal data of a billion Indians sold for ¬£6 (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/04/india-national-id-database-data-leak-bought-online-aadhaar?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )

The personal information of more than a billion Indians stored in the world‚Äôs largest biometric database can be bought online for less than ¬£6, according to an investigation by an Indian newspaper

** From the ODI
------------------------------------------------------------


** An open approach to investment banking (https://theodi.org/an-openapproach-to-investmentbanking?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID] )
------------------------------------------------------------
In a report published today, we consider the investment banking sector‚Äôs data infrastructure, where data assets are on the Data Spectrum, and challenges and opportunities in using open data to create a strong data economy


** What are the impacts of peer-to-peer accommodation platforms? Read and comment on our research (https://theodi.org/blog/what-are-the-impacts-of-peertopeer-accommodation-platforms?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID])
------------------------------------------------------------
As part of the ODI‚Äôs innovation programme, a new project is looking into ways in which data can help improve the peer-to-peer accommodation sector. New research has been published and is open for feedback


** Using artificial intelligence and open data for innovation and accountability  (https://theodi.org/blog/using-artificial-intelligence-and-open-data-for-innovation-and-accountability?utm_source=ODI+Master+list+%28Only+Phil%29&utm_campaign=fd2eaf8672-TheWeekinData05Jan2018&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3391a19d97-fd2eaf8672-101341833&mc_cid=fd2eaf8672&mc_eid=[UNIQID])
------------------------------------------------------------
In the light of the UK‚Äôs new industrial strategy and budget ‚Äì and the ODI‚Äôs recent participation in a House of Lords evidence session around how AI and personal data should be owned, managed, valued and used for the benefit of society ‚Äì the ODI‚Äôs Head of Technology Olivier Thereaux examines our work in this area

News: Secrecy over international relations trumps transparency of EU-Turkey deal

Madrid, 8 February 2018 - The General Court of the European Union has ruled
that the public does not have the right to access the European Commission's
legal advice on the March 2016 EU-Turkey...

 Secrecy over international relations trumps transparency of EU-Turkey deal
 Madrid, 8 February 2018

 Click here <https://www.access-info.org/article/30307>
to read this article online.

 The General Court of the European Union has
<http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=199184&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=549666>
ruled
<http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=199183&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=549666>
that the public does not have the right to access the European Commission's
legal advice on the March 2016 EU-Turkey agreement on returning migrants
and asylum seekers from Greece to Turkey.

 The Commission had applied a series of exceptions to documents requested
by Access Info Europe <https://www.access-info.org/>
, documents that the court process revealed included late night emails
between high level public officials discussing legal and political aspects
of the controversial deal.

 The judgments shed further light on the scope and application by the EU
Commission of the international relations exception contained in the EU
Transparency Regulation, a provision for which there is no public interest
override. In this case, access was refused because of the risk of harming
international relations with Turkey.

 ‚ÄúThe deference to secrecy of international relations is of great concern
on an issue like this where human rights are at risk,‚Äù stated Luisa
Izuzquiza, Communications Officer at Access Info, who submitted the
original requests.

 ‚ÄúInternational agreements such as the EU-Turkey deal have a huge impact
in the lives of millions of people, especially those of refugees that seek
shelter in Europe - greater transparency is crucial to ensure their rights
are being respected,‚Äù added Izuzquiza.

 The Court ruling and the court proceedings do, however, reveal new
information as it contains a detailed description of each of the documents
- something that the Commission had failed to do - hence unveiling the
last-minute, behind-the-scenes, nature of the decision making that led to
the EU-Turkey deal.

 In particular, the judgments show that the Commission consulted with its
Legal Service on aspects of the EU-Turkey deal such as the consideration of
Turkey as a ‚Äúsafe country‚Äù, appeals procedures in Greece to deal with
asylum applications, aspects of Greek legislation, or return and
resettlement of refugees. Documents also contain legal queries from the
Netherlands, which at the time were in charge of the Presidency of the
Council.

 This is what we now know about the EU Commission's legal advice
<https://www.access-info.org/ref/30299>
¬ª

 ‚ÄúThanks to Access Info's access to documents requests and legal
challenge, information about how this decision was taken, who were the
actors involved, and most importantly, the types of legal concerns the
Commission had while negotiating deal, was unveiled,‚Äù said Helen
Darbishire, Executive Director of Access Info Europe.

 Access Info noted that the two judgements issued on 7 February 2016 also
confirmed the Commission's application of two other exceptions: protection
of court proceedings, and protection of legal advice, with only a minimal
win for Access Info Europe to a couple of sentences from two of the
documents.

 ‚ÄúThe judgments are important in that they set out with precision the
scope of the EU transparency rules and the criteria to be met by EU
institutions when refusing access to documents. Where the judgments are
novel is that the Court ruled that the protection of legal advice was
applicable in this case due to the particular nature of the documents and
the very particular circumstances of the case,‚Äù commented Onno Brouwer,
the lawyer representing Access Info.

 Access Info Europe brought this case against the EU Commission after
having submitted two access to documents requests asking for the
Commission's own evaluation of the legality of both EU-Turkey statements:
the 8 March 2016 statement
<https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2016/03/08/eu-turkey-meeting-statement/>
, and the statement known as the EU-Turkey deal
<https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2016/03/18/eu-turkey-statement/>
, of the 18 March. The Commission refused access to all documents except
selected paragraphs of one; a decision Access Info challenged
<https://www.access-info.org/article/27029>
before the General Court in December 2016.

 The judgment of both cases are available online here
<http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=199184&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=549666>
(Case T-851/16) and here
<http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=199183&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=549666>
(Case T-852/16).

 For more information, please contact:

 Luisa Izuzquiza, Communications Officer | Access Info Europe

 Helen Darbishire, Executive Director | Access Info Europe

 Send an e-mail <http://www.access-info.org/about-us>
or call +34 609 707 264

** Bonjour Jo√´l,
------------------------------------------------------------

Quelle substituabilit√© entre covoiturage et lignes de train ?
Le rapport Spinetta sur le ferroviaire en France, rendu public la semaine derni√®re, pointe le co√ªt pour les contribuables des lignes de train les moins emprunt√©es, lesquelles repr√©sentent 16 % des d√©penses pour seulement 2 % des passagers. Partant du principe que le train n‚Äôest plus le seul mode de transport motoris√© accessible, le rapport pr√©conise la fin du financement des lignes (https://Le-lab.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=1eb3177a0dd6e2d1c99e91493&id=3c9691ce36&e=a09396796a) dont ¬´ l‚Äôint√©r√™t socio-√©conomique n‚Äôest pas d√©montr√© ¬ª.

Mais par quels moyens de transport remplacer ces lignes ? Des navettes autonomes sillonnant le territoire, ou encore la transformation des lignes en voies r√©serv√©es √† ce type de v√©hicules semblent peu cr√©dibles √† moyen terme, la fili√®re des v√©hicules autonomes √©tant loin d‚Äô√™tre op√©rationnelle (https://Le-lab.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=1eb3177a0dd6e2d1c99e91493&id=7715d8d602&e=a09396796a) .

Quant au covoiturage, son d√©veloppement pourrait se faire... sous certaines conditions. Des chercheurs soulignent que les pouvoirs publics doivent offrir des √©quipements facilitant cette pratique (https://Le-lab.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=1eb3177a0dd6e2d1c99e91493&id=b19d9ec13b&e=a09396796a) , afin qu‚Äôelle puisse profiter √† tous : aires d√©di√©es depuis lesquelles le passager peut effectuer une demande, centrales t√©l√©phoniques pour les personnes ne disposant pas de smartphones, etc. La Communaut√© d'agglom√©ration de l'Ouest Rhodanien (COR) a ainsi mis en place le service Covoit'ici (https://Le-lab.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=1eb3177a0dd6e2d1c99e91493&id=29e8f1b3f0&e=a09396796a) , qui permet aux passagers d'entrer en contact avec les conducteurs depuis des bornes install√©es au bord de la route. Les sommes √©conomis√©es suite √† l'arr√™t de lignes peu rentables pourraient √©galement √™tre investies dans d‚Äôindispensables incitations financi√®res ou fiscales, pour que les automobilistes se saisissent massivement de ces prati
ques.

Reste la question de l'impact environnemental du remplacement des trains par des voitures ou des cars. Cet enjeu ne semble pas pris en compte dans le rapport. Ne sont pas non plus explor√©es des strat√©gies pour augmenter la fr√©quentation de ces lignes, une alternative qui permettrait pourtant de justifier leur co√ªt... et de ne pas voir leurs contraintes de mobilit√© augmenter pour les 2 % de passagers d√©pendant de ce moyen de transport .
